A Note about this version of the E-Z Guide

This version of the E-Z Guide now contains detailed information about each vehicle. This comes from the Revs Volunteers’ training material. To access the detailed information from the summary bullet pages, touch the “DETAILS” link on any page. After paging through the detailed description, touch the “RETURN” link to go back to current summary.

This version also contains information on the banners and murals in the collection.

'49 Porsche 356SL/Gmünd

CURRENTLY UNDERGOING RESTORATION

·         Established long-term form for product

·         One of 50 built in Austrian ex-sawmill

·         Hand-hammered  aluminum bodywork

·         Used to set endurance records - France

·         Aerodynamic 'spats' helped attain speed

·         Powered by ‘modified’ VW pushrod engine

Station #3 – Automobility – From Elemental to Elegant

’83 Columbia Three Track Tricycle

·         Many elements of the first automobile

·         Rack & Pinion steering, two wheel drive

·         Introduced chain drive & 2 speed gearbox

·         'Differential' axle for smooth cornering

·         “Three Point” stability improved safety

·         Appealed to Ladies & riders of all ages

 

DETAILS

STATION LIST

VEHICLES C

 

 

’85 Humber Ordinary 58 Inch Bicycle

·         Innovative 1:1 gearing example

·         Large driving wheel - faster speeds

·         Wire wheels replaced iron-shod type

·         Rubber tires improved grip/ride

·         Nicknamed "Penny-farthing" - British coins

·         First machine known as “Bicycle”

·         Improved version of ’17 Hobby-Horse'

·         Pedals and spring improved control, ride

·         Beginning of personal mobility

·         Nicknamed “Bone Shaker” - harsh ride

·         Michaux, Paris and Olivier brothers - builders

Station #4 – Automobility – From Exclusive to Mass Value

 

'89 Trabant Type P601L

'56 Volkswagen Beetle "Modified"

 

'89 Trabant Type P601L

·         “Iron Curtain” personal mobility

·         East German Cold War “Beetle”

·         Two cylinder, 2 cycle engine - ‘smogger’

·         Body built of cheap plastic cloth - “Duraplast”

·         Gravity feed fuel supply, tank over engine

·         Only thing available - public loved them

·         Designed to proletarian parameters

·         Served oil exploration in Arabia

·         Popular for police, Alpine rescue work

·         Dual flat-twin engines, light construction

·         French iteration - ‘car for the masses’

·         Citroen logo based on synchromesh gear

'12 Hispano-Suiza Alfonso XIII Torpedo

·         Example of conserved preservation

·         Original, unrestored condition - Still runs

·         One of seven known to exist

·         Painted radiator shows good cooling

·         Swiss Birkgit designed ’05 - ’38 “Hissos”

·         Built 50000 WW 1 aircraft engines

·         Arguably the first Sports Cars

·         Had shock absorbers, early Rudge wheels

·         “Boy King” Alfonso’s favorite runabout

·         Based on  'voiturette' racer of 1910

·         Exceptional handling, brakes in period

·         Restored ‘in-house’ at Revs shop

'12 Mercer Model 35-C Raceabout

·         America’s first sports car

·         Minimal body, standard race rule gas tank

·         Accessory ‘monocle windshield’, spotlight

·         In ‘11 won 5 of 6 major races entered

·         70 mph; brakes barely adequate

·         Arch-rival of Stutz Bearcat

Station #6 – Vitesse - Some 'Aces' of the Roaring Twenties and Thirties

'29 Sunbeam 3 Liter Twin Cam Super Sports

·         First British car to win a Grand Prix race

·         First dual overhead cams production car

·         $6750 $$$ - 90 mph, complex engineering

·         Tire widths: 12 inch front, 16 inch rear

·         1.5 liter engine based on BMW 2002

Banners & Murals

 

The banners and murals displayed around the Collier Collection have been selected with great care to assist the visitor in understanding who some of the pioneers and ‘guiding lights’ of the automotive industry were and why we recognize them today.

These exhibits have been placed primarily in three areas:

First, in the main lobby, both overhead and on the walls; second, around and above the adjacent mezzanine (just four steps up), and, third, above and around the South Annex between the Second Floor and South ‘Vitesse’ galleries.

The individuals shown are some of the entrepreneurs, engineers, constructors, competitors and other visionaries who contributed to the development of automobiles of today.

This brief summary does not include the literally hundreds of high-resolution photomurals that line the walls throughout the exhibit galleries.  These have also been selected to describe the events and details which are important parts of the stories of the vehicles shown here.


 

Mezzanine – above

Harley J. Earl (1893– 1969) pioneer designer   

·         Shown in Le Sabre –’50. First head of G.M.Design

·         Father of the Corvette and Concept/Show Cars

·         Introduced chrome, two-tone paint, hardtops, tail fins & wrap-around glass

 

Ernest Henry (1885–1950) engine designer   

·         Shown ca. 1912

·         Swiss engineer who brought us now-universal double overhead cam engines

·         Initially worked for Peugeot

·         Work also brought racing wins for Hispano-Suiza, Ballot and Sunbeam 

 

 

Mark Birkigt (1878–1953) engineer           

·         Pictured 1904

·         Designed all Hispano-Suiza automobiles From 1904 to ’38 

·         Swiss native; Spanish company

·         Cars regarded as superior to Rolls-Royce

·         Also designed WWI aircraft engines

 

Henry M. Leland (1843–1932) entrepreneur  

·         Pictured in 1911 with grandson Winfred Jr. 

·         Father of interchangability. Inventor

·         Inspired Kettering to develop self-starter

·         Later, founder of Cadillac and Lincoln

·         Champion of civic causes

 

 

 

Alfred P. Sloan (1875 –1966) corporate leader

·         Pictured in 1939

·         Shaped General Motors; CEO from 1920s to ‘50s

·         Pioneered four-wheel brakes, ethyl gas and new front suspension

·         Built concept of cars for every price level

·         Major philanthropist

MANUAL SECTIONS START HERE

 

 

McLAREN 1995 F1

Serial No.  022

V 12-cyl 60-degree DOHC 4 valves/cyl. 6064 cc 369.9 cu in

627 HP at 7400 rpm Wheelbase: 107” Weight: 2244 lbs.

HP to WT Ratio: 3.58

 

The McLaren F1 was the ultimate street car of the Twentieth Century. That was the consensus of the motoring press, and certainly McLaren’s intent. Who better to unseat Ferrari, Lamborghini, Bugatti and Jaguar than the factory that had accumulated five consecutive Group 7 (Can Am) world championships, three Indy 500 victories and six Formula 1 titles?

Put to the task of creating McLaren’s ultimate street car was Gordon Murray, who became famous designing the Brabham race car that caused the phrase “ground effects” to be coined. The secret to Murray’s aerodynamics was a full ground effects under-tray which incorporated air entering the venturi channel below the front bumper between the flanking radiator openings. Engine air is ducted through the roof and a rear spoiler that only pops up when braking, which applies down force on the rear, to compensate for nose dive.

What the F1 doesn’t have is telling as well: active suspension, four-wheel drive, power steering, and anti-lock brakes. The reasoning was that the first two add weight, the third dulls steering response, and ABS brings lack of driver control.

The F1’s body, a monocoque hull made wholly of carbon fiber, was styled by Peter Stevens. One of Gordon Murray’s early ideas was that the passengers would be literally staggered into a “rear” seat in a one-plus-two seating configuration. The center driving position means that one doesn’t “get into the car” so much as “installs oneself in the car”. Once the dihedral door is swung upward and forward, the driver rolls rump-end first across the left-side passenger area, swinging their feet down into position.  The owner’s manual provides a diagram.

In the motoring world the F1 was as avidly anticipated as the various incarnations of Star Wars. With a top speed of 240 mph (set by McLaren with the prototype car in stock configuration at VW’s test track) and 0-60 in 3.4 seconds, it did not disappoint. A total of one prototype and 68 production F1 McLarens were built from 1993 to 1998.

 

RETURN

 

 

LOTUS 1962 Elite Series II S.E.

Serial No. EB 1661

4-cyl. SOHC 1216 cc 95 HP at 7200 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 15.33 Wheelbase: 88” Weight: 1456 lbs

 

In the mid-fifties Colin Chapman’s small shop in the north of London employed about a half dozen workers, three moonlighting designers from Ford’s Dagenham styling studio and a bunch of college student volunteers who built the Lotus race cars that had taken motor sport by storm. For his first road car, Chapman lifted the front suspension from his Formula II car, while the engine was developed from his Lotus Eleven’s Coventry Climax.

Precedent was of little moment to Colin Chapman. He shattered it in the Elite by devising a chassis/body construction of stressed fiberglass, which provided the lightweight that was the Chapman gospel. Body shaping was courtesy of Peter Kirwan-Taylor, an accountant who liked to draw cars, with tweaking by Lotus aerodynamicist Frank Costin and Ford stylist Ron Hickman.

The prototype was the sensation of the Earls Court Auto Show in October 1957. Producing the car in premises little larger than a two-car garage was obviously untenable. Through Kirwan-Taylor’s contacts, a million dollars was secured for a two- story factory in Cheshunt. Lotus Engineering Company became Lotus Cars Ltd.

The world’s most advanced GT car received rapturous reviews. Its monocoque construction meant engine / driveline noise inside was stereophonic. The stressed roof meant an open version was impossible. These were minor inconveniences to enthusiasts who relished motoring in a coupe that was a metaphor for “driver’s car” and would win its class at Le Mans six years running.

Unfortunately, money was lost on each Elite built. Worse, Porsche now introduced its 356 Super 90, which was equally fun, cost a thousand dollars less and could be fixed easily. Chapman couldn’t build the Elite any cheaper and an aftermarket maintenance network was nil. Production ceased in 1963 after few more than a thousand units. Colin Chapman wanted to stay in business. The Elite was too advanced for his companies own good. Ten times as many of its successor, the conventionally structured Elan designed by Hickman, would be sold.

 

RETURN

 

 

ABARTH SIMCA 1964 2 Mila Corsa

Serial No. 1360067

4-cyl. DOHC 1946 cc (119 cu in) 204 HP at 7200 rpm

Wheelbase: 82” Weight: 1455 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 7.58

 

“Over seven thousand victories!” crow devotees of the small cars bearing the scorpion logo of Carlo Abarth. The expatriate Austrian founded an Italian racing dynasty in the spirit of Modenese neighbor Ferrari, by using racing to prove and promote his products. Unlike his illustrious contemporary, who crafted fabulous thoroughbred automobiles, Abarth’s empire was based on selling speed equipment, conversion kits and complete “Abarthized” Fiat mini-cars to budget-minded performance fanatics.

In 22 years, Abarth created over 200 distinct models. This unparalleled proliferation of cars, predominantly based on Fiat products, reflected a glorious Italian defiance of rational manufacturing discipline. Abarth’s output was largely “hot-rodded” sedans and only modestly different from their Fiat and Simca siblings. A few world- class racers were brilliantly confected, and Abarth totally dominated international small displacement racing during the 1960s.

One such example, the Abarth Simca series was produced under contract with that French manufacturer to create a performance image. Abarth combined the Fiat- derived Simca 1000’s economy car chassis, suspension and transmission with sleek bodywork and all-Abarth engines to produce a potent GT competitor. First introduced in 1.3 liter form in 1962, the Simca promptly won that class of the World Manufacturers’ Championship. The two liter version was added in 1963. It garnered only frustration because its 192 horsepower regularly destroyed the transmission. Nevertheless, when sprint speed mattered over endurance, the two liter could humble Porsche and Ferrari, as it did in winning the 1964 European Hill Climb Championship. With Chrysler’s acquisition of Simca in late 1964, Abarth’s contract ended. He continued to build Simca-based racers for some years. In 1971, Abarth sold out to Fiat, who cancelled the racing program in favor of another new subsidiary, Ferrari.

 

RETURN

 

ALFA ROMEO 1964  GTZ

Chassis No. 750 052

4-cyl. DOHC  1570 cc 175 H P at 6500 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 9.43

Wheelbase: 86.8” Weight: 1650 lbs

 

Because the GTZ had a single purpose, amenities were overlooked. The car was spartan, noisy and hot. The space frame of small bore tubing weighed little mo re than a hundred pounds but it had to carry only the engine, suspension and running gear. Over that, Zagato craftsmen fashioned svelte but flimsy coachwork.

The GTZ was formidably light and blindingly fast. Gear changes from 4th to 5th at 110 mph were easily accomplished.

The display car was the most successful car of the four GTZs entered at Sebring in1964 by factory-aided Scuderia Saint Ambroeus. Chuck Stoddard and Jim Kaser won the 1600 GT class, finishing the twelve hours with a maladjusted clutch that necessitated “crash-box” shifting. This GTZ’s only competition had come from an Abarth-Porsche, Jim Clark in a Lotus Cortina and a couple of Elans. Following the race, the car was bought by Dr. Paul Tenney with Alfa support for a season of successful SCCA racing.

Early in 1965 the company decided to back a quasi-independent organization called Autodelta - in the charge of ex-Ferrari, ex-Alfa man Carlo Chiti - to turn the new competition car into a race winner. Enzo Ferrari had done this very well for Alfa in the thirties, and Chiti was to do likewise.

It was a new beginning. Alfa Romeo was back where it belonged.

 

RETURN

 

PORSCHE 1964 904 Carrera GTS

Serial No. 904 046

2-liter (1966cc) DOHC 4-cyl. Air-cooled mid-engine

180 HP at 7000 rpm Wheelbase: 90.6” Weight: 1435 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 7.97

 

The 904 was produced because Porsche needed a new car for the 1964 season to continue winning two-liter Grand Touring Championship races.  Regulations dictated a 100 unit minimum production. This worried Porsche since never before had the factory sold more than 35 or so of any single race car. So the 904 was designed to be streetable too.

Ferry’s eldest son, Ferdinand “Butzi” Porsche III, who at 28 was heading Porsche’s new styling department, designed a fiberglass (GRP) body that was bonded directly to the sheet metal chassis’. Given the size of the production run, the body/frame assembly was contracted out to aircraft builder Heinkel. Unfortunately, the “spray and chopper gun” manufacturing system gave inadequate control over body panel thickness. Thus a 904 was usually vastly heavier (from 100-200 pounds) than its homologated weight-which tended to irritate purchasers. Height of the 904 was a mere 42.0 inches, which made getting into it difficult for a sizable driver. Yet, despite all, the car was a winner. Porsche 904s took on Ford, Ferrari and Abarth at the Targa and finished one-two in the GT class.

At Le Mans, Porsche’s record with the 904 was five entries, five finishers in the top twelve. Among races in which the display car competed in 1964 were Bad Nerrenahr, the Targa Florio and the Nürburgring 1000 km.

In addition to the structural problems of the body and the 904’s unforgiveness of driver error, its gearbox was a handful, its engine obsolete. But the car’s charisma was everlasting. While other superannuated Stuttgart competition cars lay forgotten in fields, back garages or dusty corners of racing shops, the 904 became the first collectible racing Porsche. Some say the 904 is the most beautiful Porsche road car ever built.

 

RETURN

 

 

FERRARI 1965 250 LM Berlinetta GT

Serial No. 6217

V-12-cyl. 60-degree SOHC 3286 cc 320 HP at 7500 rpm Wheelbase: 94.4” Weight: 1874 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 5.86

 

Enzo Ferrari tried once too often. Subterfuge, and perhaps a good dinner with vino concealing veritas, persuaded CSI officials to homologate the front-engined 250 GTO in the Gran Turismo category for 1962, despite only 39 of the required 100 cars having been built. The subterfuge involved giving the 250 GTO odd serial numbers (Ferrari competition cars were serialed evenly), a ruse Enzo used again with the GTO’s successor rear-engine 250 LM for the 1965 season. This time he was summarily turned down. Following the “fool me twice” doctrine, CSI officials also had been subjected to a vociferous protest by Carroll Shelby. Enzo Ferrari’s rage was beautiful to behold but he knew he had lost.

Placed in the prototype class overlapping Ferrari’s faster 365 series of cars, Enzo declined to race the 250 LM in 1965. Independents took over. Divine salvation arrived with U.S. Ferrari distributor Luigi Chinetti’s North American Racing Team (NART). Veteran Masten Gregory and Jochen Rindt decided to drive their LM absolutely flat out until the car broke. As faster prototypes, including the Ford GT-40 in its maiden effort, retired, the Gregory-Rindt pair worked up the leader board and ultimately won.

In 1966, CSI officials slashed GT class homologation build minimums to 50. Both Ford’s GT-40 and Ferrari’s 250 LM were now Gran Turismo class competitors. Ford dominated Le Mans for the next two years. The 250 LM performed admirably on several continents courtesy of the independents.

The display car was delivered in January 1965 to Edoardo Lualdi-Gabardi and completed in Italian hill climbs for 15 months. Returned to the factory, it was then sold to Canadian Michael McDonald. In 1970 the car was sold to the Gelles brothers of New York State and campaigned during that decade in Ferrari club events. No. 6217 was also owned by David Lucas in New Zealand and STPO in Germany before joining the Collier Collection in 2005.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1949 356SL Gmünd Coupe

Serial No. 3003 (356/2 055)

Flat-four air-cooled pushrod VW-type rear-engine Porsche cylinder heads 1498 cc 72 HP at 5000 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 28.89

Wheelbase: 82.7” Weight: 1430 lbs

 

In late September of 1951, this racing Gmünd coupe in record-breaking tune was driven around the Montlhéry banking for 72 hours at 94.66 mph, to a new world record. The car, powered by the then experimental 1500 Super engine, was one of the original aluminum bodied Austrian-hand built Gmünd coupes that were used for racing purposes after Porsche had returned to Germany in 1949. Known as project 356 from the design sequence that started when Porsche opened his independent design studio in Stuttgart in 1931, the new car was brought to reality by Ferry Porsche working under the watchful eye of his father. Gmünd coupes were hand-hammered out of sheet aluminum over wooden bucks.

Made obsolete by the first Stuttgart produced steel bodied 356s, because of their lighter weight and availability, several of the unsold Gmünd cars were modified for competition and catalogued as 356SLs and renumbered as 3000 series cars.

In addition to a new serial number series, SL configuration involved such visible differences as louvered steel quarter "windows", full wheel spats, streamlined aluminum belly  fairings, pedestal-mounted shifter and, for Le Mans, a third roof- mounted wiper arm, remote oil filter and driving-lights. Gmünd coupes carried the Porsche name into competition for three years at Le Mans as well as in several rallies where one finished first in class and third overall.

The first appeared at Le Mans in June 1951, where it won its class. The subsequent successful speed record attempt with this car came that September at the high-banked Motherly circuit just outside of Paris.

While the exact number is debatable, less than fifty Gmünd coupes were built in 1949. At some point a handful with serial numbers above fifty were assembled in 1950 after the factory returned to Germany.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE – Fiberglass Buck 1953 550-01 Coupe

 

This ‘full scale’ modeling buck was manufactured by Joe Cavaglieri in 2005 from the replacement GRP (‘glass reinforced plastic’ aka “fiberglass”) body panels commissioned by Salvador López Chávez circa 1957. Having purchased 550-01 from Jaroslav Juhan, Mr. Chávez competed with the aluminum bodied car in numerous events under the sponsorship of his shoe-producing company “Calzado Canadá S.A.” of Guadalajara, Mexico. Showing signs of significant wear and tear, the decision was made to replace the original body with a fiberglass replica.

This work was completed in Mexico City by a furniture maker whose workshops had learned to handle GRP. The original body was used, making molds from its surface and, step by step, cutting away the original body panels. The result was a rough, but authentic replica of the original body; hand- hammered in 1953.

In the restoration shop of Mr. Cavaglieri, the ‘glass’ replica underwent an eighteen (18) month process of reworking; where “…proper cutlines on 550-01’s rear fenders…some of the rivet layouts…replicated dash” were all helpful clues in the long journey of bringing the aluminum bodied 550-01 back to its original grandeur. As a “splash of the real body”, the GRP replica was invaluable as a starting point for the restoration.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1953 550 Coupe

Serial No. 550-01

4-cyl. pushrod air-cooled mid-engine

1498 cc 98 BHP at 6000 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 12.24

Wheelbase: 82.7” Weight: 1200 lbs

 

By the early fifties Porsche found that modified production cars would no longer win races. A purpose built racing car would be required. The 1498cc production car engine was “improved” for higher power and fitted with twin-choke Solex 40 PII downdraft carburetors. An external oil cooler in the nose joined the wet-sump lubrication system. Porsche contracted Weidenhausen of Frankfurt for the alloy bodies of the two cars. With Le Mans in mind, a coupe was planned, but the first car finished competed as a roadster in its initial race at the Nürburgring. Because it rained, Helm Glöckler (Walter’s cousin) would have preferred the display car to have had its hardtop but he fought the wet weather, Borgward and BMW, as well as carburetion problems – and won. Victory the first time out for any race car is a good thing.

At Le Mans, Hans Hermann joined Helm Glöckler in 550-01 and two driver- journalists - Richard von Frankenberg and Paul Frère - took  550-02.  During practice with coupe tops fitted, the Porsches realized 124 mph on the Mulsanne straight but at a hellish price for the drivers. Still, claustrophobia, the lack of ventilation, and an almost unbearable noise level were inconveniences grudgingly endured for the speed advantage. The two cars were within a lap of each other for the entire 24 hours and crossed the finish line at the same interval at which they started. Le Mans scorers abhorred a tie, so a little more distance was found for 550-02, and the journalists took both the 1500 cc class and a new record.

Season’s end found the cars on their way to Guatemala and a group  of Porsche enthusiasts headed by Jaroslav Juhan who raced them in the Carrera Panamericana in Mexico (550-02 took its class) and the 1000-Kilometer Race in Buenos Aires (550-01 won) as well as at Sebring, among other races. The 550 showed three continents Porsche was serious about racing.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1959 718 RSK Spyder

Serial No. 718-007

Flat-four air-cooled mid-engine  DOHC 1498 cc 150 HP at 7200 rpm Wheelbase: 82.7” Weight: 1240 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 8.27

 

The display car is distinguished by the company it kept. Wolfgang von Trips, Jo Bonnier, Edgar Barth, Umberto Maglioli and Paul Frère were among the drivers who raced it. During a busy season in 1959, the car competed at Spa, the Targa Florio, Nürburgring, Le Mans, the Rheims Formula II race, the Gaisberg hillclimb and Goodwood. At the Targa, 718-007 established the fastest lap and led consistently until a last lap suspension failure took away victory.

This 718-007 was one of the third series of RSKs distinguished by wishbone rear suspension and a simplified rear chassis to ease in-car gear set changes. It was one of two factory cars converted to center steering to allow participation in Formula II races. Engines larger than the 1500 cc originally intended, tended to overheat with only the surface cooling bonnet. The display car ran with both 1600 and 1700 engines during a season prompted by the factory’s determination to try once more for the world sports car championship. Porsche RSKs had almost won it over Ferrari in 1958 and would again in 1959.

Once the RSKs were put into competition in 1958, there naturally arose a craving among amateur sportsmen for Porsche’s latest racing weapon. For 1959,

37 customer cars were built - mainly with a 550A style oil cooler to simplify maintenance and the 1958 RSK’s 550A-based low pivot rear swing axle. Customers could also purchase the center-steering hardware, and four of them are known to have done so.

In October of 1959, this 718-007 was sold to John von Neumann, in California, where Tim O’Reilly drove it for the remainder of that season. In 1961 Steve Herrick was the owner/driver. The following year, 1962 Ralph Woods was owner and Steve Froiner the driver. Active in SCCA competition on the West Coast for several more years, 718-007 concluded its eclectic career as an autocross car.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1956 550A Spyder

Serial No. 550A-0139

4-cyl center mounted air-cooled engine DOHC 1498 cc  135 HP at 7200 rpm

Wheelbase: 82.7” Weight: 1170 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 8.67

 

Despite its designation, this Spyder was a brand-new model. The 550A carried on the Giant Killer image begun by the 550, but did so with better manners.

The engine was the same: the Dr. Ernest Fuhrmann-designed air-cooled flat four that combined gear and shaft driven double overhead cams, roller bearing crankshaft, twin ignition, dry sump lubrication. The 550 had a ladder chassis, but the 550A had a space frame, which made a huge difference. Chassis weight was cut by up to 95 pounds and rigidity increased. This allowed another 60 pounds to be taken off the all-aluminum body - which made a considerably faster car. Impeccable handling was the 550A’s long suit.

Spyder man Ken Miles said the difference was “almost unbelievable.” Still, if the predecessor 550 confused drivers in a turn (one couldn’t be sure where the car would end up) and the successor RSK scared them to death (the tail breaking away viciously without warning), winning remained a constant with all Spyders.

Class victories for the 550A were so commonplace - except for the last Mille Miglia in 1957 where Umberto Maglioli’s 88.31 mph average, 5th overall and 1st in class was Porsche’s best ever in that Italian classic. But for sheer audacity it didn’t compare with the trip to Sicily in 1956 for which Porsche racing director Huschke von Hanstein took just one 550A, driver Maglioli and two mechanics. The 1.5-liter Spyder won the Targa Florio outright, defeating a trio of 3.5 Ferraris, three 300SL Mercedes and a gaggle of Maseratis.

“The greatest long-distance racer in the world” was Ken Miles’ assessment of the Spyder. Demanding to be driven well, these Porsches provided intensive course work for an entire generation of drivers who graduated from Spyders to stardom: von Trips, von Frankenburg, Barth, Moss, Bonnier, Behra, Gendebien, Ginther, Gurney, Holbert, Jennings, Gregory, and Penske. The list goes on and on. “We were certified sports-car nuts,” wrote John Jerome nostalgically, “and we needed something to believe in.” The Spyder kept the faith.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1960 RS-60

Serial No. 718-041

Flat-four air-cooled mid-engine DOHC

Wheelbase: 86.7” Weight: 1280 lbs

1697 cc 170 HP at 7800 rpm. HP to WT Ratio: 7.53

 

The Sicilian Targa Florio mountain road course event was held from 1906 through 1973. With its twists and turns and elevation changes, it was the perfect venue for Porsche, stressing balance performance over outright speed. This RS60 won the Targa in 1960, and continued to win seven first overall finishes during the decade. Ferrari took the remaining three.

The RS60 was the last version of the Type 718 Spyder line, being carried over in production until the following year, mechanically unchanged, but redesignated as a RS61.

Wheel size was reduced an inch (to 15), and four inches added to the wheelbase for better legroom and more docile handling. The new larger 10-inch FIA-decreed windscreen cost the cars 5-6 mph in top speed, a penalty not suffered by the more powerful competition.

A second in the Nürburgring 1000 followed the display car’s Targa win. In spite of fellow team cars having a good season as well, Maranello Ferraris won the war. Totting up the points at season’s end showed a Ferrari-Porsche tie, but the FIA’s more-total-victories bonus gave the 1960 Manufacturers Championship to Ferrari for the fifth straight year.

The last important race for the display car was the Nürburgring 1000 in May 1961 where rain tires (a gamble lost when the sun shone) put Stirling Moss woefully behind until the rain returned and Moss made up for lost time in a masterful display of driving that quickly saw him in second, gaining on the leader and thrilling the crowd - until 718-041’s engine gave out.

In addition to racing, 718-041 served the factory as Porsche’s guinea pig to test various transmissions and the 2.0-liter Type 587 engine.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1961 RS-61L

Serial No. 718 048

Flat-eight air-cooled mid-engine DOHC

1982 cc 210 HP at 8200 rpm

Wheelbase: 90.7” Weight: 1420 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 6.76

 

 

This was the last of the cars that Bob Holbert drove to his SCCA E Sports Racing Championships in 1961 and 1962, as well as the newly-created U.S. Road Racing Championship in 1963. Holbert's success was no big surprise. He was America's top Porsche driver.  But this Porsche surprised Holbert.

In 1961, Porsche (diverted from sports car racing by its Formula 1 effort) relied on the aging 718 series to supply its racing customers with a new weapon. The only significant revision to the RS-61 over the RS-60 was the number change in its name. Holbert had ordered the chassis/body you see here after crashing his first RS-61. Upon delivery, he discovered that his new car was four inches longer in the engine bay area to accommodate Porsche’s latest race engine. Concurrent with development of the 1.5-liter eight-cylinder engine for Formula 1, Porsche developed a two-liter sports-racing version to try in lieu of the venerable Fuhrmann four-cam.

The flat eight's debut took place at the Targa Florio in 1961. Two eight-cylinder cars were entered; one crashed, the other finished third.  Nürburgring likewise brought a third and a d.n.f. Holbert's chassis was apparently an unneeded back-up to the so- called "Grossmutter," the W-RS Spyder (718-047) that Porsche used with such good results at so many events. Because the lighter-weight Fuhrmann four-cam was serving Bob so well, and he felt the long wheelbase car handled better than the W-RS, this RS-61L never raced with the eight-cylinder unit. Nevertheless, the car is now fitted with the engine for which this chassis was designed, though it can easily be converted back to the Holbert configuration.

 

RETURN

 

 

ELVA – PORSCHE 1963

Serial No. 70/069

Flat four air-cooled mid-engine DOHC 1679 cc 183 HP

Weight: 975 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 5.33 Wheelbase: 90.6” Mfg: 19

 

This is one of 19 Elva-Porsches produced in 1963 and ’64 by Englishman Frank Nichols, founder of Elva Cars (the name is derived from the French “elle va” meaning “she goes”). The factory co-operated fully in the project (even to the extent of lending its name to it), and eventually purchased one to defend its hill climb title in 1964. The program was clearly aimed at Porsche’s customers seeking a suitable replacement for the aging, and increasingly uncompetitive Type 718 Spyders.

Discussions in late 1962 between factory representatives and then U.S. Elva importer Carl Haas led to the decision to create the hybrid sports racer; the first of which was delivered to Haas in time for the 1963 August Road America 500. The “500” was one of the country’s premier road course events at the time. Despite its small 1.7-liter displacement and relatively low power output, it won. This performance led to numerous orders for 1964.

In all, 15 Elva-Porsches came to America. However, despite the Road America victory and the second third places in the ‘64 United States Road Racing Championship, their quirky handling (caused by widening its tubular frame at the rear to accept Porsche’s broad-beamed engine), and less than perfect braking not only didn’t endear them to their drivers but it led to their early departure from the sport’s top ranks.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1958 Carrera  GT Speedster

Serial No. 84461

Flat-four air-cooled rear-engine DOHC  1587 cc 160+ HP at 8000 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 10.82 Wheelbase: 82.7” Weight: 1732 lbs

 

From the mid 1950’s into the present 21st  century, the four-cam Carrera four cylinder engine and the 356 Speedster have dominated the Sports Car Club of America’s (SCCA’s) National Championship arena, as well as  international competition. As remarkable as the 356 Carrera GT story is, it is overshadowed by that of Maryland’s Bruce Jennings, a racer so closely associated with the four-cam Porsche that he became known simply as “Mr. Carrera.”

This Carrera Speedster was one of three that Jennings owned, set up for medium- speed courses and includes an aluminum hood and deck lid, external oil cooler, special shocks, heavy duty sway bar, front annular disc brakes and RSK turbo-finned rear drum brakes . His other two GT’s were set up for a short and a long course, depending on the suspension and gear ratio but all painted the same colors.

In Europe the majority of 356 Carrera GTs were coupes, but in America the bulk of those seen in the SCCA were Speedsters. Movie stars such as James Dean and Steve McQueen raced them with success. However, no one was as successful as Jennings, who won the national title multiple times.

This car, nicknamed “Mahidabel,” took Jennings to two of those crowns, one in 1960 and the other in 1963, after “Pup” Pupilidy, had driven it to its first National championship in 1958. Together, its 67 triumphs and it three championships make it the winningist Carrera GT of all time.

From the collection of Bruce Jennings – one of three of his original race cars.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1960 Abarth-Carrera GTL

Serial No. 1001

Flat-four air-cooled  rear-engine DOHC 1587 cc  135 HP at 6500 rpm.

Wheelbase: 82.7” Weight: 1762 lbs HP to WT Ratio:13.05 Original price: $6,200+-

 

At Le Mans in 1960 the display car saved Porsche’s honor by being the only factory entry to finish…and by winning its class. The new Italian-bodied Carrera was faster than the German original.

In mid-1959, absorbed with its Formula 1 program, Porsche sought outside help to keep its aging GT Carreras competitive. The factory settled on Italian coach-builder Zagato to build 20 lightweight bodies for the standard 356B chassis. The company asked Austro-Italian Carlo Abarth (a go-between in the Porsche-Cisitalia project over a decade earlier) to oversee the project. Without Porsche’s knowledge, Abarth hired Franco Scaglione, formerly of Bertone to design, and the Viarengo & Filipponi Coachworks to build, the new body.

Over five inches was chopped off the height, under five inches was cut from its width and by eliminating the bumpers, and a full five inches came off its overall length. Frontal area was reduced 15% and weight by over 100 pounds. The availability of the Abarth-Carrera - at $6,200 more or less - was a complete sellout.

The display car, the first built, arrived at Porsche in early spring of 1960. The Porsche men were distressed by what they received. So - out came the interior; the front fender openings had to be enlarged to permit full steering lock, and the car’s overheating was cured by putting louvers in the engine lid. The GTL finished 2nd in the sports class at the Nürburgring on its first outing.

At Le Mans this car, driven by Herbert Linge and R.J. Walter, was the factory’s sole GT entry. It was timed at 138 mph on the Mulsanne straight. Unfortunately for Linge and Walter, the race was a wet one. The Abarth body allowed water in, the Porsche floor pan didn’t let it out. Seats and floorboards were awash most of the 24 hours.

Subsequently, this car won its class at Monza and the Tourist Trophy before finishing out its career as a hillclimb racer for Swiss privateer Siegfried Lang.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1964 904 Carrera GTS

Serial No. 904 018

2-liter (1966cc)  DOHC 4-cyl. Air-cooled mid-engine  180 HP at 7000 rpm

Wheelbase: 90.6” Weight: 1435 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 7.97

 

The 904 set the pattern for a whole generation of racing Porsches, but its beauty cloaked the fact that it wasn’t as aerodynamically perfect as it might have been, besides being overweight, too. It used the aging but reliable 180 horsepower Carrera four-cam unit. The 904 was undeniably tough, with its fiber glass body bonded to a sheet steel double-box chassis. It was certainly effective enough a performer to put Porsche back in the hunt for 2-liter class domination.

The 904 made its racing debut at Daytona in February 1964, where a single car finished sixth overall and won its class. Another 2-liter prototype class win at Sebring followed, though this time the 904 - the actual car shown here, driven by Briggs Cunningham and Lake Underwood - came ninth overall. Once the obligatory 100 units were produced the homologation as a GT class racer followed.

A 2-liter flat-eight prototype 904 appeared at the Le Mans test weekend, and a few weeks later led the Targa Florio for three laps of the 45-mile circuit, but its suspension failed and did not finish. Another 904 driven by the Sicilian Baron Pucci and Colin Davis, crossed the line in first place, with another 904 second.

In all, the standard 904 notched up an encouraging total of class wins and overall wins during the remainder of the 1964 season, taking the 2-liter GT Championship for Porsche.

The 904 had a lot of untapped potential, said its designer “Butzi” Porsche, but the 1964 launch of the 911, whose completely new six-cylinder engine and modified MacPherson Strut front suspension represented a clean break with Porsche tradition, rendered the 904 obsolescent. By 1966, it had been swept out by Porsche cousin Ferdinand Piëch and his Carrera 6.

Acquired from the collection of Briggs Cunningham.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1964 Type 911 a-Series

Chassis No. 300-128

 

One of the two first 911’s delivered to the United States.

 

Brumos Porsche received the car for demonstrations. As Porsche said “anybody who wanted to drive a 9011 just had to get to Brumos and they could test drive the new 911”.

Jack Ryan, who was a racecar driver and owned a VW dealership in Atlanta, made a deal to buy the car from Brumos in 1965.  He then had the idea to race the car at the

24 Hours of Daytona in 1966. Huscke von Hanstein, the Porsche Director of Motorsport at the time, did not like this idea.  He basically frowned at the idea of racing a new 911 at the Daytona 24. He didn’t think the car was ready yet because Porsche would have brought one to race if they thought it was ready to complete for 24 hours. Jack Ryan said “It’s my car now & I’m entering it”. About half way through the race, Jack Ryan, Lin Coleman & Bill Bencker were leading their class. Crazy as it sounds…Huscke came down & offered them any assistance they needed. The car went on to win its class, thus being the first 911 ever to win a road race…not just in America, but in the world. Another 911 had won the Monte Carlo Rally in 1965, but that was a rally, not a road course

 

·      1966: It was the first 911 to race at the famous Daytona race track, finishing first in class.

·      It was also the first 911 to race at Sebring, finishing second in class.

·      It went on to win many more races in the SCCA and in Club Racing.

·      The car still retains its original engine and transmission and the interior (minus the headliner) is completely original too.

·      The car was hit at one point and front right fender and door were replaced.

·      The original color was black.

 

RETURN

 

PORSCHE 1967  911R

Serial No. 11899005R

Flat-six air-cooled rear-engine SOHC 1991 cc 210 HP at 8000 rpm Wheelbase: 87” HP to WT Ratio: 8.62

Weight: 1810 lbs Manufactured: 23

 

Despite its innocuous appearance, this car represents Porsche’s only attempt at the homologation game. Its object was to build a small number of radically fast racers that appeared to be in compliance with GT class minimum production rules. Shuffling serial numbers or, more usually, claiming only minor (and hence legal) development of a production series, resulted in a car with prototype speed racing in the GT class. The GTO Ferrari was probably the most notorious example.

The competition success of the street 911S and the 911T suggested the wisdom of an ultimate 911 weapon. Except for its steel unibody, roof, and quarter panels, the 911R body shell, built by Karl Baur, is 100% fiberglass. So thorough was Porsche’s weight saving that the cars were even fitted with special oil tanks in front of the right rear wheel, ultra-light taillight assemblies and front turn signals. Even the epoxy plastic door handles unique to these cars saved possibly a pound. With weight under control, Piëch specified the potent Carrera 6 power plant. Wide alloy wheels were fitted at all four corners.

Porsche attempted to homologate the new car as a 911S variant, but with 50 more hp and at least 350 less pounds, the FIA wasn’t buying the story. Market research indicated that selling the 500 units now necessary for homologation couldn’t be done profitably, so the 23 911Rs thus far built (including three prototypes) were destined to finish their competition careers in non-production categories or as rally cars where homologation wasn’t necessary.

The car on display is the most successful 911R built.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1966 906 Carrera 6

Serial No. 906125

6 cyl. air-cooled mid-engine OHC 1991 cc

HP to WT Ratio: 6.48

210 HP at 8000 rpm Wheelbase: 90.6”  Weight: 1360 lbs

 

The Carrera 6 succeeded the 904. Porsche had effectively retained its iron grip on the under-two-liter GT class with the 904. But Ferrari threatened to break that grip with the new, fast V-6 Dino. A return to tubular space frame technology was desirable since repairing the 904’s chassis/body was difficult with the old bonding technique making for variations in chassis rigidity. The requirement to build a street/race car that had dictated the design of the 904’s box section frame no longer applied. GT regulations for 1966 now required 50 and not 100 unit production, a sales quota Porsche’s marketing men were confident could be reached with purpose-built racing cars.

But more significant was the entrance on the scene of another of Dr. Porsche’s grandsons: 28-year-old Ferdinand Piëch, the new head of Porsche R&D. Clearly, he was not about to accept his predecessor’s concept, because it was not the best way to go and he was a new broom.

The new Carrera’s flat-six engine, derived from the production 911 and originally intended for the 904, would now power numerous racing Porsches. The Carrera 6 layout followed the 904 pattern. Unlike its predecessor, the 906’s slippery new shape was designed in the wind tunnel.

After the car’s debut at Daytona in early ‘66, everyone called the Carrera 6 a success. It finished 6th overall and won the two-liter prototype class. The first showdown with Ferrari’s new Dino was at Sebring seven weeks later. The Carrera 6 won. History would demonstrate such a result was not atypical. The Dino might be quicker, but the Carrera 6 was tougher.

More importantly, with the advent of the Carrera 6, Piëch launched an era of unparalleled progress at Porsche, designing at least seven new cars, several new engines, all in a period of five years. Many of these cars are on display here.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1965 356C 1600SC Coupe

Serial No. 221877

Flat-four air-cooled pushrod rear-engine 1582 cc 95 HP at 5800 rpm

Wheelbase: 82.7”  Weight: 2080 lbs

HP to WT Ratio: 21.89

 

The 356C was the final development of the 356 series, begun a decade-and a-half earlier with the Gmünd coupe. In 1965, Miles Collier was given this then brand new 356C as a high school graduation present.

Introduced at the Frankfurt Automobile Show in September 1963, the 356C primarily differed from its immediate predecessor, the 356B by its new four-wheel disc brakes, a logical response to the car’s 115 mph top speed. The 356C was available with three different models: the pushrod 75 horsepower C, and the 95 hp SC, as well as the four-cam 130 hp two-liter Carrera by the end of its model life, over 76,000 356s had left the Stuttgart factory; an amazing number for this “niche” sports car.

Over the years of its production, the 356 did not significantly change in appearance, except perhaps for the “facelift” given the series in 1960. Bumpers and headlights on the new 356B were raised to comply with U.S. requirements, and a large chrome hood handle was fitted.  Subsequent model years are almost indistinguishable.

The 356 series’ classic appearance belied the intense development program going on under its skin. Through the years the original Volkswagen components had been replaced piece by piece with similar but 100% Porsche-designed parts. The VW- derived 1100 cc engine of 1950 gave way to a 1300, 1500 and ultimately 1600 cc pushrod unit. The Porsche bits themselves often changed year by year as parts were reengineered for better service and reliability.

Clever marketing was never needed to sell the 356. The Porsche sold itself to a generation of increasingly sophisticated enthusiasts. Certainly no sporting marque in history has commanded more unflinching loyalty than the Porsche.

Purchased new by the Collier Family.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1967  910/6

Serial No. 910 007

Flat-six air-cooled SOHC 1991 cc fuel injected

220 HP at 8000 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 6.00

Wheelbase: 90.6” Weight: 1320 lbs

 

This car won the Nürburgring 1000-kilometer race in 1967. It wasn’t the most significant victory in Porsche history, but it was perhaps the most sentimental. An overall win in Germany’s most prestigious sports car race was finally achieved after a decade of trying. The home team won before the home crowd.

Joe Buzetta and Udo Schutz formed the incongruous driver pairing for this car. The American was small, the German huge. As the car hurtled into the air over the ‘Ring’s famous jumps, the smaller driver’s feet left the pedals and his body floated off the seat. “It was dangerous as hell” said Joe but such was the price paid for a proper public relations victory. Finishing behind this Porsche were two more 910/6s.

Despite Porsche’s best racing season in years, the factory lost the prototype championship to Ferrari by a single point. The under-two-liter trophy was Stuttgart’s, but Porsche wanted more.

In the quest for overall victory, Ferdinand Piëch ruthlessly pared excess weight from his cars. Only in this way could the small-displacement Porsches challenge the bigger cars. Piëch disdained racing because of the role that uncontrolled variables, including driver talent, could play. Such factors - luck, we would say - often militated that the inferior solutions would win over the superior. To him, the optimal race would test cars on a chassis dyno over a simulated race course.

Because real racing was the game, Piëch played to win… So highly stressed were the racing cars due to the search for lightness that only the brand-new ones were used to contest important races. After a single-factory outing, the “used” cars were routinely reconditioned and sold to private teams. Accordingly it was not unusual for Porsche to produce thirty to fifty cars per year in its own race department. This is as close as you can come to the Vince Lombardi query, “If winning isn’t the only thing, why do they keep score?”

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 917K 1971 (Martini)

Serial No. 917 019

Flat-twelve air-cooled mid-engine DOHC  fuel-injected 4907 cc 600 HP

HP to WT Ratio: 2.93

Wheelbase: 90.6”  Weight: 1760 lbs.

 

The ink on the contract making John Wyer manager of Porsche racing for 1970 was barely dry when Wyer was stunned to find out his most significant opponent, in addition to the usual Italians, would be.….Porsche.

Austrian Porsche Konstruktionen, known familiarly as Porsche Salzburg, was the team of Louise Piëch, whose son Ferdinand (his grandfather’s namesake and Ferry Porsche’s nephew) headed the factory racing program. Despite Porsche Salzburg’s status as an independent, familial ties insured that Frau Piëch would receive new development pieces as soon as, and sometimes before, Wyer’s official factory team.

For most of 1970, this didn’t matter. Porsche Salzburg won Le Mans but Wyer’s Gulf Porsches dominated the season. The 917 won every major race entered except the Sebring 12-Hours during which a new and hastily developed larger front hub bearing failed on all cars entered.

The display car was one of the original batch of 25 917’s built by Porsche in the Spring of 1969 in order to qualify the 12-cylinder coupe as a member of the five-liter Group 5 class. During 1970 this car served as a spare entry for the Porsche Salzburg team In 1971, 019 raced as a member of the Martini Racing Team. Again, the Piëch team took Le Mans, the winning car driven by Helmut Marko and Gijs van Lennep. The car was sporting numerous experimental features including a magnesium tube frame. And again, Wyer’s Gulf Porsche team dominated elsewhere and won the championship for the second consecutive year.

From the collection of Vasek Polak.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1969 917 PA

Flat-twelve air-cooled mid-engine DOHC fuel injected

4494 cc 580 HP at 8400 rpm

Wheelbase: 90.6” Weight: 1710 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 2.94

 

Without this car, Porsche’s total domination of Canadian-American Challenge Cup racing might never have happened. Group 7 - was a class constrained by few rules. Porsche’s first entry in this new venture would race as an underdog, a role the firm knew well.

The decision to enter the Can-Am series was made mid-season 1969. Porsche would provide the car, driver Jo Siffert and a full support crew; the new Porsche & Audi Division of Volkswagen of America would sponsor the entry. The contract signed, the only problem remaining was making a Group 7 racer out of the Group 5 917, and doing it fast.

The PA was a 917 without the top. The 100 or so pounds saved was offset by the 56 gallons of fuel required to run these sprint races nonstop. The engine was strictly stock, all 4.5 liters.

Five races had already been missed. In the six that remained, thanks to its endurance racing reliability, the 917 PA finished in all but one, took second once - and placed fourth overall in the Can-Am Championship. Porsche was encouraged.

The rest is well-recorded history. The 917PA underwent many modifications over the years, enjoying a long career that lasted well into the mid 1970’s. This car raced in more Can-Am races than any other Group 7 car and remained competitive until its retirement when the Can-Am series died for lack of competition.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1969 908 LH

Serial No. 908 025

2997 cc DOHC fuel-injected Flat-8 air-cooled mid-engine 350 HP at 8400 rpm  Wheelbase: 90.4” HP to WT Ratio: 3.86 Weight: 1350 lbs

 

In 1967, Porsche lost the World Championship of Makes by one point. So the factory decided to even the odds. The FIA's new three-liter prototype (Group 6) and five-liter sports car (Group 4) regulations adopted for 1968 presented the opportunity.

The 2.2-liter 907 started the 1968 season with wins at Daytona, Sebring and the Targa Florio. The 908 followed shortly, enjoyed few victories with mechanical failures - and lost the 1968 championship to Ford's GT-40.

Meanwhile, the 4.5-liter Type 917, built hard on the heels of the 908, was ready for homologation in 1969, but typically was too green to spearhead the Porsche world championship attack. That chore fell to the trouble-plagued 908, which by now had received such major changes as an aluminum space frame, a newly- designed crankshaft, 15-inch wheels and a new five-speed transaxle.

In 1969 the display car won at the ultra-fast Spa circuit in Belgium with Jo Siffert and Brian Redman driving. This 908 LH was no easy car to drive fast. Beautiful but imperfect aerodynamics made the car weave back and forth as speeds approached 200 mph. Brian Redman summed up his feelings for the display car, saying "it scared me stupid." Terrified or not, Redman set fastest lap at 145.28 mph (a new course record) on his way to victory.

The most successful long tail campaigned by Porsche, this car also came second to a sister 908 LH at Monza and retired with a broken countershaft gear at Daytona. That one victory, a second and a d.n.f. were sufficient for top honors is explained by simple mathematics: to win the world championship in 1969 Porsche built a total of 52 brand-new racing cars. By contrast, John Wyer won the championship the year before using only three Gulf-sponsored GT-40s. But numbers were irrelevant to Ferdinand Piëch. Just consider how many new racing Porsches appeared during his era. Admittedly, each was a logical extension of the other - and was unmatched by any racecar builder anywhere.

Note:  currently under restoration

PORSCHE 1971 908/3 Prototype

Serial No. 90803 013

Flat-eight air-cooled mid-engine DOHC Fuel-injected, 2997 cc 360 HP at 8400 rpm  HP to WT Ratio: 3.22 Wheelbase: 90.6 “ Weight: 1200 lbs Mfg: 13

 

The intensity with which Porsche pursued the world championship in 1970 and 1971 is indicated by the 908/3. It was produced to win two races: the Targa Florio and the Nürburgring; both twisty, difficult tracks where the 917's size and power were a handicap.

The 908s predecessor had been built as coupes or spyders. The 908/3 was produced only as a spyder, and would be dubbed the "miracle Porsche" by the Italians.

Only the engine remained the same, and it gave away at least 65hp to the rival three-liter 312PB Ferrari. Though the 908/2 had been easily the lightest car in its class, the 908/3 was lighter yet by a full 100 pounds through the extensive use of titanium. Its space frame weighed but 48 pounds; its plastic and foam body another 26.5.

Just 13 908/3s were produced: eleven in ’69-’70, two in ’71. Racing pundits predicted widespread structural failures because of their lightness. They were wrong. A one-two finish in both the Targa and Nürburgring in 1970 saw to that. The ’71 Targa was a driver error fraught crash out, a three car sweep of the `Ring put the final event back on the track.

The only 908/3 breakages occurred in the two cars built in 1971 and only because their frames had not been built to specification. The display car was one of them. Still, at the 1971 Nürburgring, Pedro Rodriguez and Jackie Oliver joined in the three-car Porsche sweep, nursing this car across the finish line to second place despite a broken chassis.

The 908/3’s win rate was an astounding 75%. The car’s basic design remained competitive for more than a decade. With the 908/3, Piëch and company moved far from the 910 design-of-the-month days. A 1971 configuration 908/3 won its last World Championship race at Silverstone, England in 1980.

 

RETURN

 

 

PORSCHE 1970  914/6 GT

Serial No. 9140432542

Flat-six air-cooled mid-engine SOHC 210 HP at 8000 rpm

Wheelbase: 96.4” Weight: 1980 lbs

HP to WT Ratio: 9.43

 

The Le Mans competition debut of the 914/6 GT would have been better noticed had it been any other year. Sixth overall and first in GT was a superb maiden effort especially for a two-liter car. It paled to insignificance in 1970 in light of the 917’s three- car sweep and Porsche’s first-ever outright win. However, Porsche salesmen were clearly pleased with the 914/6 GT’s performance. Competition success might spur sales of the 4-cyl. model that VW-collaborated on that had opened to mixed reviews in the enthusiast press instead of the more usual raves that greeted new Porsches.

Just 3,350 six-cylinder variations of the 914-6 were built. The power train was all Porsche. The GT’s were further upgraded with 911S brakes (908 brakes for long-distance racing), extra chassis stiffening, steel fender flares, front oil cooler, fiberglass bumpers and deck lids. Displacement remained two liters as homologated. A full Carrera 6 top end on the engine upped horsepower to as much as 210. Unfortunately for the 914/6, the same money could buy a 2.5-liter racing 911 that would give its owner a much better chance for high overall wins. As a result, few 914s were raced privately.

The display car was one of three Porsche 914/6 GTs entered in the Marathon de la Route at the Nürburgring in August 1970. Sprint speed was unnecessary in this 86-hour car-punishing event, so the engines fitted were stock 911S units putting out 160 hp at 7200 rpm. Racing 908 front brake calipers with their thicker brake pads were installed. This car ran in the Group 4 production category; the other two, with slightly wider rear wheels, raced as prototypes.

After three-and-a-half days of racing only 23 of the 64 starters remained. The three 914/6 GTs were ahead of the rest of the field by a wide margin. They lined up to cross the finish line in a blaze of orange glory. How “punished” were they? One taillight bulb was broken, a couple of window cranks were loose, two fuses had blown, one tire had gone flat - in an aggregate 18,000+ racing miles. That’s amazing racing!

 

RETURN

 

 

COLUMBIA THREE-TRACK TRICYCLE 1883

Produced by POPE MFG. CO. Boston, Mass.

Distributed by OSBORN & ALEXANDER San Francisco, CA

 

The innovation of this vehicle resides just below its rider’s seat; the “differential drive” gear set that permits both wheels to be driven equally and for the smooth variation of speed as the vehicle rounds corners. Variations of this gear arrangement are utilized in all axle driven vehicles.

‘Lady-like’, unprovocative conveyances were dictated by Social mores of the time; and this vehicle provided that for ladies and gentlemen alike. The stability of the three wheel platform provided improved safety over the normal two wheeler and the adjustability of the controls permitted children to the “oldest inhabitant” to ride the same machine.

An optional “Power-Gear” two speed gearbox controlled by a plunger mechanism was an option for this vehicle; creating a low gear for climbing hills and a high gear for descending hills and level ground. The option does not appear on this particular example, but the frame does have the mounting position for it; it was a twenty dollar option at the time of order placement on a base price of $160.00 for the model you see before you; a tidy sum for the late 1800’s.  As a company advertisement of the day stated:

“The exercise of ‘cycling does not strain: One moves as softly as the rain from heaven, Astride the wheeled horse.”

 

RETURN

 

 

1885  HUMBER

58” Ordinary

 

In the absence of gearing, early velocipede makers discovered that making the driving wheel larger enabled the rider to go faster. So the front wheels grew in size while the rear wheel shrank. This evolutionary process saw the wood-spoked iron-shod wheels replaced by light, strong, wire wheels with solid rubber tires. The result was the “ordinary” bicycle, nicknamed “penny-farthing” by British bicyclists because the disparate size of the wheels reminded them of the large and small copper coins then in circulation (there were four farthings to a penny, 240 pennies to a pound). This “penny-farthing” was built by one of the oldest British manufacturers, Humber of Nottingham, which had built its first bicycle in 1870. The vogue of the fast but perilous high-wheeled ordinary was short-lived; Humber built their last in 1892, as chain-drive “safety cycles” with equal-sized wheels took to the roads in ever-increasing numbers.

 

RETURN

 

1869 VELOCIPEDE

Bicycle

by La Compagnie Parisienne

 

The first effort toward personal mobility was made by Baron Karl von Drais in 1817 in Saxony. He devised a rudimentary wooden two-wheel “running machine” which the rider straddled and propelled by running his feet along the ground. It was the first vehicle with 2 wheels placed in a line. The “running machine” became known under various names: Draisine in Germany, velocipede (fast feet) or Draisienne in France, hobby horse or dandy horse in England.

In the early 1860s Pierre Michaux of Bar-le-Duc in North-East France had the bright idea of fitting pedals to the front wheel of an old “hobby-horse” to create the first bicycle. He put a refined version of his invention into production and called it a “velocipede”; riders jarred by the iron tires called their machines “boneshakers”. Crude though it was, the velocipede spurred a transportation revolution that led inexorably to the motorcar.

Michaux and his son Ernest continued making velocipedes until 1869, when they sold their business to the Olivier brothers of Paris, who traded as La Compagnie Parisienne and built the boneshaker you see here. Like most velocipedes, it’s fitted with the ingenious twist-grip brake invented by Ernest Michaux.

 

RETURN

 

 

PANHARD & LEVASSOR 1896  Wagonette

Serial No. 593

Two-cylinder in-line engine, two valves per cylinder Atmospheric overhead inlet valve/side exhaust valve 1650cc 6 hp

Wheelbase: 72” Weight: 1800 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 32.24

 

Emile Levassor had the devil’s own time with his first try at a horseless carriage. After mounting the engine amidships, he put his car on the road in 1890 and got nowhere, literally. Workmen in the factory in Paris lampooned partner René Panhard’s name into Pannehard (“panne” or “breakdown”).

Levassor persisted and came up with a revolutionary idea: engine in front, gearbox behind it, drive to the rear wheels. This layout gave the world the first automobile that did not betray horse-drawn carriage antecedents. And it worked. Breakdowns ceased. Orders poured into the factory. Would-be manufacturers everywhere copied the Système Panhard.

Over the next few years the Panhard et Levassor factory became a model for the aborning industry, filled with state-of-the-art tools from America, Germany and those designed in-house including woodworking equipment (René Panhard’s specialty) to make the acacia wheels.

Levassor was arguably the first to recognize the good business sense of motor sport competition. He took top honors in the 1894 Paris-Bordeaux-Paris race single-handedly: 745 miles in just under 49 hours. His epic drive was the talk of the Continent. Levassor didn’t slow down. Following a serious accident in the Paris-Marseilles race of 1897, ignoring his doctor’s orders to rest, he collapsed and died over his drawing board.

This car was delivered to M. Peneau of 58 Rue De La Boetie, Paris (a very affluent area of central Paris) on February 28, 1896. The price of 6590 francs included fitted luggage, a roof rack and a cover for the luggage. 5 liters of gasoline were included for 80 francs extra. It is believed that the buyer was himself in the automobile manufacturing business for a short time and also produced wine, owning Chateau Peneau in the Bordeaux region of France.

In 1900 Panhard was making 75 cars a month using proprietary engine units supplied by Daimler; more than any U.S. automaker and more than most in Europe. But in 1901, came another revolutionary idea to copy: a Daimler named by its distributor for his daughter Mercedes. The Panhard was instantly obsolete. Panhard & Levassor’s subsequent career was checkered, its end sad. In the mid-sixties the company was sold for neither its name nor its car.  Citroën simply needed more factory space.

 

RETURN

 

 

BENZ 1901 Dos-á-Dos

Serial No.  3317

2-cyl., four-stroke, opposed engine  2690 cc

10 HP at 920 rpm Wheelbase: 70.5” Weight: 1716 lbs HP to WT Ratio: 171.6

 

At the end of the 19th century, Carl Benz was the largest automobile manufacturer in the world. Sales in 1900 totaled 603 cars; 341 were sold outside Germany. When our display car was sold to industrialist Julies Oswald Römmele in Freiburg, it was said to be the first automobile in town.  Dos-á-Dos means to sit - “back-to-back”.

In 1936, the fiftieth anniversary of the first automobiles, this Benz was selected for exhibition. By then the Third Reich was intruding with increasing intensity into private industry.

Because Hitler was obsessed with the glorification of German history, Römmele’s car was commandeered after the celebration. As war clouds gathered, it was moved to a salt mine near Dresden, a safekeeping measure afforded such other German cars as the all-conquering Mercedes-Benz and Auto Union GP racers.

When peace came, Dresden was in East Germany and the Römmeles lost track of the car. Not until the Berlin Wall fell in 1989 could the family look for their Benz. It was found on display in Dresden’s Verkehrsmuseum. Nearly five years of red tape later, the car was returned to the Römmele family where it remained until acquired by the Collier Collection in 1999.

 

RETURN

 

 

DELAUNAY-BELLEVILLE 1908

Roi des Belges Tourer by Mulliners Ltd.,

Birmingham Chassis No. 1406V Engine No. 1406V

6-cyl. L-head 5900cc HP: 28 HP to WT Ratio: 136.75 Wheelbase: 139” Weight: 3829

 

Sir J. Milne Barbour, Bart., proprietor of a thread factory in County Antrim, Ireland and original owner of the display car, was both very rich and very conservative. “No owner ever drives his Delaunay,” a rival French automaker commented. “It just isn’t done.” Like the Locomobile in America, the Delaunay-Belleville was a symbol of dignified wealth.

The hyphenated name - emerged when naval engineer Louis Delaunay married his boss’s daughter and adopted her name. The company had been a producer of dreadnought boilers for the British Admiralty.  The Belleville factory in St. Denis boasted a thousand employees in 1900 and was well-equipped to enter the automotive arena. In 1903 Marius Barbarou, veteran of Benz and Clément, was hired to set up a Delaunay- Belleville automobile division. Fitted with a round honeycomb radiator referring to the company’s boiler-making tradition, the car itself made its debut at the following year’s Paris Salon.

This new car offered both functional and aesthetic advantages over the competition. The Delaunay adopted the full-pressure lubrication system, which Belleville had patented in 1897 for marine engines.

The display car was the first example the company produced using a six-cylinder engine. A Delaunay-Belleville could approach 60 mph and stay  there indefinitely. Some of the big sixes were documented to have traveled 200,000 miles between overhauls.

This marque was a favorite with Nicholas II, the last Tsar of Russia; the company used his image in its publicity and named one of its models “SMT” (Sa Majesté le Tsar) in his honor.

Although Delaunay-Belleville manufacturing continued for decades, the glory days of “The Car Magnificent” ended in 1912 with Marius Barbarou’s departure and Louis Delaunay-Belleville’s death. When the factory finally closed in 1948, it was used to manufacture the Rovin minicar.

 

RETURN

 

 

FORD 1909 Model T Touring

Chassis No. 9043

4-cyl. L-head 176.7 cu. in. 22 HP at 1600 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 65.91 Wheelbase: 100” Weight: 1,450 lbs Original price: $850  Mfg.: 16 million

 

The Model T had no gauges, an owner didn’t know how hot his engine was, how fast he was going, or how much fuel he had left. But he could buy what he needed. An entire industry grew up to provide “Tin Lizzie” with what she didn’t have: anti-rattle devices, shock absorbers, single shot lubricators, faux hoods, V radiators. Even speed equipment should you want to take the old girl racing. This car has an alloy body, brass plated handles and green body color – very rare. Most Model T’s were steel bodied and black “dipped”.

The Model T dominated the low-priced automobile market. Henry Ford’s obsession had not been to produce a cheap car - the industry was littered with those, most of them awful - but to produce a good, sturdy and dependable car cheaply. In August 1913 when the assembly line at Ford’s Highland Park moved for the first time, he owned that market. By October the time necessary to build a Model T had been reduced from twelve and a half hours to six, by year’s end to an hour and a half. As mass production was refined, the price of a model T, which had been introduced in 1908 at $850, was progressively decreased to a low of $290 in 1924. More than 16,000,000 “Tin Lizzies” had been sold when the Model A replaced her in 1927.

Following the First World War, every other car on the globe was a Model T Ford. “Tin Lizzie” had changed the world. She was the single most important car in history.

ROLLS-ROYCE 1914 Silver Ghost Colonial, Kellner

Serial No. 65RB

6-cyl. 7428 cc (453 cu.in.) 40/50 HP (48.6 R.A.C.) HP to WT Ratio: 88.85

Wheelbase: 143.5” Weight: 4265 lbs Chassis price: $7,000 Mfg.: 8,000+-

 

The Silver Ghost was, with the Model T Ford, the longest-lived and most famous automobile of its era. Approximately 8,000 - including military staff cars and armor-plated versions – were built between 1907 and 1926. Its mascot name was “The Spirit of Ecstasy”. (Meanwhile Henry Ford was producing over 16,000,000 Tin Lizzies). In 1913 the Colonial model Silver Ghost chassis was developed for sale in India. The display car has a four-passenger tourer body by Kellner of Paris.

The partnership between the Hon. Charles Stewart Rolls, third son of Lord Llangattock, and Frederick Henry Royce, a working class manufacturer from Manchester, had begun in 1904. Royce was the engineer, Rolls the enthusiast. In 1907, their new 40/50 model received its more popular designation after a tourer painted silver was driven 15,000 miles and then dismantled under Royal Automobile Club (R.A.C.) supervision. All parts were inspected and reported in “as-new” condition. A motoring correspondent declared the 40/50 the “best car in the world,” which the Messrs. Rolls and Royce thought was a fine slogan. It was on the Silver Ghost that the famous “Spirit of Ecstasy” mascot was introduced as well.

There was nothing really extraordinary about a Silver Ghost, but everything in it was extraordinarily well built. “A triumph of workmanship over design” was one critic’s summation. That a Silver Ghost would never wear out and that its engine was inaudible are legends only slightly exaggerated.

Then as now, quoting horsepower figures was regarded as odious by Rolls- Royce. A top speed of 80+ mph was possible in a Ghost like this one. In 1914 the New York price for a Silver Ghost chassis was $7,000. Said Rolls-Royce: “The quality will remain long after the price is forgotten”.

Acquired from the collection of Briggs Cunningham.

 

RETURN

 

 

 

DUESENBERG 1930 J Phaeton LeBaron

Serial No. 2349

8-cyl. DOHC 4 valves/cyl. 420 cu. in. 265 HP at 4200 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 19.89

Wheelbase:  142.5” Weight:  5270 lbs Chassis price new: $8,500

 

“265 Horse Power…116 Miles Per Hour,” The Motor headline screamed in 1928. “…Chassis priced at $8,500.” The new Model J Duesenberg’s power and performance would excite the public. The Duesenberg policy excited the American coachbuilding industry: all cars were to be custom made.

Since the close of World War I, the idea of tailoring an automobile to personal preference had enjoyed wide appeal amongst people who could afford to spend from half-again to considerably more than the chassis price to put a body on an automobile. Custom body houses - many descendants from prominent 19th Century carriage builders - flourished. The Duesenberg seemed heaven-sent to perpetuate that pleasant situation.

No two Duesenbergs were alike. How custom a car was depended upon the customer. If desired, an entirely unique creation could be had. Most clients preferred to go with variations on the themes in Duesenberg’s portfolio. The company had sent advance blueprints of the chassis layout to America’s top coachbuilders to invite design sketches for consideration for that portfolio. Chassis layout included radiator grill, hood, headlamps, fenders, running boards and bumpers to preserve marque identity. The remaining identity was the coachbuilder’s.

Over twenty American coachbuilders dressed the Duesenberg, none more handsomely than LeBaron Carrossiers of New York City. Rhythmic curves were a company forte. The “sweep panel” LeBaron dual cowl phaeton proved to be the most popular four-door Duesenberg. And of the several LeBaron designs for Duesenberg, this one was the most popular as well. Total LeBaron production for the Model J was thirty-three bodies.

Custom coachwork crashed with Wall Street and firms failed with rapidity during the Depression. Just Derham and Inskip survived the Second World War, only to succumb soon after. As for LeBaron, it was bought by the Briggs Body Company of Detroit, which in turn was acquired later by Chrysler. Chrysler chose to revive the name in its model line-up. LeBaron’s custom tradition remained history.

Acquired from the collection of Briggs Cunningham.

 

RETURN

 

 

DUESENBERG 1935 SSJ

Serial No. 2594

DOHC 8-cyl. 4-valves per cyl

448.141 cu. in. 350 HP at 5000 rpm HP to WT Ratio: 12.70

Wheelbase: 125” Weight: 5080 lbs Chassis price: $8,500 Mfg: 2

 

Lexicographers differ whether the proper spelling is “Duesie”, “doozie” or “doozy,” but they all agree that the word coined in the 1930s as a convenient metaphor for anything so singularly grand or formidable as to defy the usual Webster offerings. Its derivation, of course, was the Duesenberg Model J.

The J idea belonged to automotive empire builder Errett Lobban Cord; its execution was attributed to engineer Fred Duesenberg. Enormously successful as a racecar producer, Duesenberg was a lamentable businessman. His Indianapolis company was heading for financial disaster when Cord acquired it in 1926. Yet Cord told Fred to design a car the likes of which America had never seen, cost was to be no object.

Introduced in December 1928, the J Duesenberg was unabashed overkill - massive, weighty, of heroic proportion everywhere. Its race-inspired straight-eight engine boasted over twice the horsepower of its nearest American competitor. In 1932, when the 265 HP J was supercharged to become the SJ, horsepower jumped to 320, the factory advertising 129 mph in top gear. With ram’s head manifolding, as on the SSJ you see here, horsepower climbed further.

Only two examples of the “super-short” 125-inch SSJ chassis were ever produced. (Standard wheelbase lengths were 142 - and 153 - inches.) Gary Cooper bought the car you see here. Not to be upstaged, Clark Gable quickly decided he had to have a Duesie “just like Coop’s” and talked the local dealer into lending him the other one.

Duesenbergs tended to be purchased by people who were famous. America’s most expensive luxury car by far ($8,500.00 for the chassis alone), its flamboyance attracted movie stars, maharajahs, trendy royals, dynamic tycoons, even a gangster or two. Just 480 Duesenbergs had been built when E.L. Cord disbanded his automobile empire in 1937.

A half century later the Duesenberg remained a legend.  Appropriately, it was an uncompromisingly superlative car.

Acquired from the collection of Briggs Cunningham.

PIERCE-ARROW 1915 Model 48  B-3

Serial No. 13251

477 cu.in. 48 HP 6-cyl. T-head Dual Valves

HP to WT Ratio: 100.17

Wheelbase: 142” Weight: 4808 lbs

The Pierce-Arrow of Buffalo descended from a company that originally manufactured birdcages. The Pierce-Arrow was – one of the “Three P’s” (with Peerless of Cleveland and Packard of Detroit) in the U.S. luxury car field.

During the Gay Nineties, the upstate New York firm had successfully added bicycles to its household product line. Its first automobile, however – a steamer – was a failure. Thereafter Pierce turned to gasoline engines. The small single cylinder Motorette evolving into the mighty 4-cylinder Great Arrow by 1904. Beginning in 1905, a Great Arrow won the inaugural and three subsequent Glidden Tours. These victories brought the company national fame. In 1907 a 6-cylinder model was added. In 1909 the name Pierce-Arrow was adopted.

By 1915, when this $4900 “Runabout with Victoria Top” was marketed, Pierce-Arrow had built its 12,000th car, a production figure exceeded only by Packard among

U.S. luxury cars. Pierce-Arrow had also become the car of choice for U.S. Presidents, starting in 1909 when William Howard Taft added two Pierce-Arrows to the White House stable. The presidential preference lasted until Pierce was ousted by Packard – in the Hoover era two decades later.

Painstaking attention to detail was a Pierce-Arrow hallmark. Extensive use of aluminum, power braking and hydraulic tappets were areas in which Pierce-Arrow pioneered. But right hand drive remained a feature until 1920. The Pierce-Arrow’s most famous idiosyncrasy – the fender-ensconced headlamps – endured from 1913 to the end – in 1938. Few people during the Depression could afford the car. Pierce-Arrow went down with luxury flags flying.

Acquired from the collection of Briggs Cunningham.

BENTLEY 1939  4 1/4- Litre, James Young

Serial No. B-181-MX

6-cyl  2-valves per/cyl  Side-camshaft

4257cc (259.76 cu. in 125 HP at 3800 rpm

HP to WT Ratio: 30.00

Wheelbase: 126” Weight: 3750 lbs

Partisans of the rough-and-tumble Bentley of the W.O. years were appalled in 1933 when Rolls-Royce introduced its first Bentley as “The Silent Sports Car”. Although the Rolls-Royce purchase of Bentley Motors had included the services of Bentley, he had not been asked to serve much. By the time the Bentley on display was produced, the engineer had long since departed for Lagonda to create a magnificent V-12 that was introduced for 1937.

Meanwhile, Rolls engineers had bored out their original 3669cc Bentley engine to 4257cc in 1936, thereby increasing the top speed of the car from 90 to 96 mph. In 1939, in a 4-Litre with special streamlined body, Captain George Eyston lapped Brooklands for an hour at 114.63mph.

From 1933 to 1940, approximately 2500 Rolls-Bentleys were built, about half of them the 4-Litre, 200 of those with the overdrive that was added for the 1939 model year and which is featured on the display car.

The display car is distinguished by the James Young coachwork. In 1951 the Museum of Modern Art in New York City exhibited eight cars to illustrate the finest in automotive design. This Bentley was among them and was described as “a carefully groomed object - rigid, poised, powerful - with a patrician urbanity of style that other schools of design have failed to render obsolete.”
